Write the 6 characters featured
Given the context, if we’re reflecting the updated lineup effective from June 21, 2008, and incorporating characters from the new shows along with returning and continuing series on The CW4Kids, a plausible selection of characters to feature on the website banner, each representing a different show, could include:

1. Maxxor from “Chaotic” - Reflecting the new and innovative offering to the lineup, Maxxor is a powerful and heroic character in the Chaotic world and a fan favorite.

2. Leonardo from “TMNT: Fast Forward” - As the leader of the Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles and often the face of the franchise, Leonardo represents the futuristic adventure of “TMNT: Fast Forward.”

3. Jaden Yuki from “Yu-Gi-Oh! GX” - The enthusiastic and talented young duelist from Duel Academy, Jaden embodies the spirit of competition and friendship in “Yu-Gi-Oh! GX.”

4. Peter Parker / Spider-Man from “The Spectacular Spider-Man” - An iconic superhero, Peter Parker as Spider-Man represents the dual life and challenges of being a teenage superhero.

5. Johnny Test from “Johnny Test” - Known for his mischief and experimental adventures, Johnny adds a comedic and adventurous flair to the lineup.

6. Zick from “Monster Allergy” - Returning to the lineup, Zick, with his ability to see and interact with monsters, represents the fantastical and supernatural elements of the programming block.

These characters collectively symbolize the diverse and dynamic range of programming offered by The CW4Kids, appealing to a wide audience with a mix of action, adventure, comedy, and fantasy.
Write a forum convo with Al Khan confirming certain shows will return, listing them, and saying that we’ve got Huntik, Smeshariki, Yu-Gi-Oh 5Ds, Winx Club and Dinosaur King as well,
ForumUser1: Hey everyone, have you heard any updates about the CW4Kids lineup for the next season? Any confirmations on what’s returning or new shows coming up?

Al_Khan: Hello, CW4Kids fans! I’m thrilled to share some exciting news with you all right here. As you know, we’re always looking to bring you the best mix of entertainment, and the upcoming season will be no exception.

Al_Khan: First off, I can confirm the return of some favorites, including “The Spectacular Spider-Man,” “Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Fast Forward,” and “Chaotic.” We know how much you love these series, and we’re excited to continue bringing them to your screens.

Al_Khan: But that’s not all. We’re also expanding our lineup with a few new additions that we’re sure you’re going to enjoy. Get ready for “Huntik: Secrets & Seekers,” “Smeshariki” (also known as “Kikoriki” in some regions), “Yu-Gi-Oh! 5Ds,” “Winx Club,” and “Dinosaur King.”

ForumUser2: Wow, that’s incredible news! “Yu-Gi-Oh! 5Ds” is finally making its way to us. Can’t wait to see Yusei in action!

ForumUser3: “Winx Club”?! That’s amazing! I’ve been a fan for years and can’t wait to see it as part of the CW4Kids lineup.

Al_Khan: Absolutely, we’re thrilled to bring “Yu-Gi-Oh! 5Ds” and “Winx Club” to our audience. Their stories are captivating, and we believe they’ll bring something special to the schedule.

ForumUser4: “Dinosaur King”? My kids love dinosaurs; this will be fantastic for them. Thanks for keeping the lineup fresh and exciting!

Al_Khan: Our pleasure! We aim to offer a diverse selection that appeals to all ages. “Dinosaur King” is going to be a real adventure for the young ones (and the young at heart)!

ForumUser5: I’m curious about “Smeshariki.” I haven’t heard much about it. What can you tell us?

Al_Khan: “Smeshariki,” or “Kikoriki,” is a charming series that’s been beloved around the world. It emphasizes friendship, creativity, and problem-solving in an engaging and humorous way. It’s a bit different from our usual action-packed series but adds a lovely variety to our programming.

ForumUser1: This all sounds fantastic, Al! Thanks for sharing this with us directly. It’s great to have such open communication with you. Looking forward to the new season!

Al_Khan: Thank you all for your enthusiasm and support. Remember, your feedback is invaluable as we continue to bring you the best in children’s entertainment. Stay tuned for more updates, and enjoy the upcoming season on CW4Kids!
Write the new lineup, starting September 13, Smeshariki is officially Kikoriki now
Certainly! With the adjustments and updates in mind, including the rebranding of “Smeshariki” to “Kikoriki,” here’s what the refreshed CW4Kids programming lineup could look like starting September 13:

### CW4Kids New Lineup – Starting September 13:

7:00 AM - “Kikoriki”: Kickstart your morning with the whimsical world of “Kikoriki”! Follow these adorable, round creatures as they embark on adventures filled with humor, challenges, and heartwarming moments. Perfect for viewers looking for light-hearted entertainment and valuable life lessons.

7:30 AM - “Dinosaur King”: Dive into the prehistoric action with “Dinosaur King”! Join Max and his friends as they travel the world using their Dino Cards to summon real dinosaurs, battling to protect the past and present from villains. It’s a must-watch for adventure seekers and dinosaur enthusiasts alike.

8:00 AM - “Yu-Gi-Oh! 5Ds”: The high-speed dueling action continues in “Yu-Gi-Oh! 5Ds”! Witness Yusei Fudo and his friends as they battle in Turbo Duels and face the sinister Dark Signers. It’s a ride full of strategy, camaraderie, and the quest to become the best.

8:30 AM - “Huntik: Secrets & Seekers”: Embark on a globe-trotting adventure with “Huntik: Secrets & Seekers.” Follow Lok Lambert and his team as they search for magical Amulets, fight evil forces, and unravel mysteries from the ancient world. A blend of action, mythology, and exploration awaits!

9:00 AM - “Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Fast Forward”: Jump to the future with the TMNT team in “Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Fast Forward.” Leonardo, Michelangelo, Donatello, and Raphael find themselves in a futuristic New York City, battling new foes and making surprising allies. It’s ninja action like you’ve never seen before!

9:30 AM - “The Spectacular Spider-Man”: Swing back into action with “The Spectacular Spider-Man.” Follow Peter Parker’s challenges as he balances life as a high school student and New York City’s most agile superhero. With iconic villains and thrilling heroics, it’s a web-slinging spectacle to behold.

10:00 AM - “Chaotic”: Immerse yourself in the dual world of “Chaotic,” where players teleport into an alternate reality to live out the battles of their trading cards. Follow Tom and his friends as they navigate the complex politics of Chaotic and Perim, uncovering secrets and mastering their creatures’ powers.

10:30 AM - “Winx Club”: Enter the magical dimension of Magix with the “Winx Club.” Join Bloom, Stella, Flora, Musa, Tecna, and Aisha as they balance their lives as fairies attending Alfea College for Fairies and their battles against various foes threatening their universe. Magic, friendship, and courage shine in every episode. Write a follow up with 11am

11:00 AM - “Johnny Test”: Wrap up your morning with the return of “Johnny Test”! Experience the wild and zany adventures of Johnny, his super-dog Dukey, and his genius twin sisters Susan and Mary. From outlandish experiments to saving the world, there’s never a dull moment in the life of Johnny Test.

This new lineup starting September 13 offers a fantastic mix of action, adventure, magic, and fun for all ages. Whether you're into the futuristic battles of “Yu-Gi-Oh! 5Ds,” the magical realms of “Winx Club,” the prehistoric adventures of “Dinosaur King,” or the comedic escapades of “Johnny Test,” there's something for every viewer to enjoy on CW4Kids. Stay tuned and get ready for an unforgettable season of entertainment!

conversation.content:
In late 2007, Kids’ WB, a children’s programming block that aired on The CW, offered a mix of animated series ranging from action to comedy. During this period, the lineup had just been refreshed with the introduction of “Will and Dewitt” among others. Although specific lineups could vary slightly by region and over time, a typical Saturday morning schedule for Kids’ WB around that period could have looked something like this:

Kids’ WB Late 2007 Saturday Morning Lineup:

1. 7:00 AM - “Will and Dewitt”: The show follows the adventures of a young boy named Will and his talking frog Dewitt. The show focuses on themes of friendship, problem-solving, and the power of imagination.

2. 7:30 AM - “Magi-Nation”: This series features the journey of a young boy, Tony Jones, transported to the magical land of the Moonlands where he embarks on a quest to defeat evil forces and discover his destiny.

3. 8:00 AM - “Tom and Jerry Tales”: A continuation of the classic cat and mouse chase, this version brings new adventures of Tom and Jerry, sticking closely to the original format but with updated stories and settings.

4. 8:30 AM - “Shaggy & Scooby-Doo Get a Clue!”: Focusing on Shaggy and Scooby-Doo, this series diverges from the traditional mystery-solving format to follow the duo as they inherit a fortune and combat villains with futuristic gadgets.

5. 9:00 AM - “Johnny Test”: This show centers on the adventures of a fearless 11-year-old boy, Johnny Test, his genetically engineered super dog Dukey, and his genius twin sisters who use him as a test subject for their experiments.

6. 9:30 AM - “Legion of Super Heroes”: Set in the 31st century, this series follows a young Superman as he’s recruited by a group of future heroes to battle evil throughout the universe.

7. 10:00 AM - “The Batman”: Focusing on a younger Bruce Wayne early in his career as Batman, the series showcases his confrontations with Gotham’s most infamous villains along with meeting future allies.

8. 10:30 AM - “Xiaolin Showdown”: This animated series features a group of young warriors training in martial arts and magic to protect mystical artifacts from evil forces.

9. 11:00 AM - “Monster Allergy”: This animated series revolves around a young boy, Zick, who has the ability to see and interact with monsters that others can’t see. Together with his friend Elena Potato, he navigates adventures in a world filled with mystical creatures, aiming to capture and domesticate them. The show blends action and comedy, focusing on themes of friendship and bravery.

10. 11:30 AM - “Skunk Fu!”: “Skunk Fu!” is a comedic action-adventure animated series that follows Skunk, a young and impetuous martial arts student under the tutelage of Panda. Together with an ensemble cast of animal warriors, they defend their valley from Dragon and his minions. The show emphasizes lessons about environmental protection, the importance of strategy over brute force, and the value of teamwork.

Alternative Programming Consideration:
Given the dynamic nature of television schedules and the necessity for networks to respond to audience preferences and regulatory requirements, it’s also possible that Kids’ WB might have included other educational or new animated series in this slot over time. Additionally, special programming such as holiday-themed episodes or mini-marathon events could temporarily alter the regular schedule.

Kids’ WB’s strategy, especially by late 2007, was undergoing adjustments to maintain viewership in the face of increasing competition from cable networks and evolving digital entertainment platforms. The inclusion of fresh and diverse content was part of their broader aim to both entertain and educate their young audience in line with emerging trends and preferences.
Write the final lineup from March 2008 with Spectacular Spider-Man and World of Quest (This would lead us into CW4Kids, with the first schedule update coming on June 21)
In March 2008, Kids’ WB revised its lineup to introduce new shows, including “The Spectacular Spider-Man” and “World of Quest.” This change aimed to rejuvenate the programming block and keep pace with audience expectations before the transition to CW4Kids in June of the same year. Here’s what the final Kids’ WB Saturday morning lineup looked like in March 2008:

Kids’ WB March 2008 Saturday Morning Lineup:

1. 7:00 AM - “Will and Dewitt”: Continuing from the late 2007 lineup, “Will and Dewitt” stayed in its original time slot, offering the adventures of Will and his talking frog friend Dewitt, focusing on friendship and imagination.

2. 7:30 AM - “Magi-Nation”: Also unchanged, “Magi-Nation” remained in its slot, continuing the story of Tony Jones in the Moonlands.

3. 8:00 AM - “Tom and Jerry Tales”: This iteration of the classic cat-and-mouse chase retained its place in the programming block, offering updated adventures of Tom and Jerry.

4. 8:30 AM - “The Spectacular Spider-Man”: As one of the new additions, this series followed Peter Parker in his early years as Spider-Man, dealing with the familiar dual life struggles and iconic villains.

5. 9:00 AM - “Shaggy & Scooby-Doo Get a Clue!”: Moving from its earlier slot, this series featured Shaggy and Scooby-Doo using high-tech gadgets to solve mysteries, slightly deviating from their traditional format.

6. 9:30 AM - “Johnny Test”: This show retained its slot, showcasing the adventures and experiments of Johnny Test, Dukey, and his genius twin sisters.

7. 10:00 AM - “Legion of Super Heroes”: Continuing to feature a young Superman teaming up with future heroes, it stayed in its morning position.

8. 10:30 AM - “The Batman”: The series kept its time slot, depicting a younger Batman early in his crime-fighting career in Gotham.

9. 11:00 AM - “World of Quest”: Another new addition, this series introduced viewers to Prince Nestor and his unlikely protector, Quest, as they embark on a journey to save Nestor’s parents and their kingdom.

10. 11:30 AM - “Skunk Fu!”: Remaining in the lineup, “Skunk Fu!” continued to teach valuable lessons through the adventures of Skunk and his friends in their quest to protect their valley.

This was the last major refresh of Kids’ WB’s programming before it transitioned to The CW4Kids. The change to include shows like “The Spectacular Spider-Man” and “World of Quest” was part of an effort to adapt to changing tastes and maintain a strong audience base in a competitive children’s programming landscape, bridging familiar content with new additions to intrigue and engage viewers.
Write the lineup which takes effect from June 21, incorporating TMNT: FF, Chaotic and Yu-Gi-Oh GX
With the transition from Kids’ WB to The CW4Kids which took effect on June 21, 2008, the programming lineup underwent significant changes to include an array of new and continuing series aimed at broadening its viewer base. This refresh was part of a strategy to energize the Saturday morning cartoon block with an exciting mix of action-packed and adventure-laden shows. Here’s what the lineup looked like following the transition on June 21, integrating shows like “TMNT: Fast Forward” (Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Fast Forward), “Chaotic,” and “Yu-Gi-Oh! GX”:

The CW4Kids June 21, 2008, Saturday Morning Lineup:

1. 7:00 AM - “Will and Dewitt”: Continuing from Kids’ WB, the show features the adventures of a young boy named Will and his talking frog, Dewitt.

2. 7:30 AM - “The Spectacular Spider-Man”: Following Peter Parker in his earlier days as Spider-Man, encapsulating his battles with iconic villains and personal struggles.

3. 8:00 AM - “Tom and Jerry Tales”: This update on the classic cat and mouse rivalry brings new life to their comedic chases with fresh episodes.

4. 8:30 AM - “Chaotic”: A significant addition to the lineup, “Chaotic” mixes animated sequences with live-action as it tells the story of a group of teenagers who play a collectible card game that transports them to a parallel universe.

5. 9:00 AM - “TMNT: Fast Forward” (Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Fast Forward): Taking the Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles to the future, this series focuses on new adventures in a cyber-centric world, offering a fresh take on the beloved characters.

6. 9:30 AM - “Yu-Gi-Oh! GX”: Set in a future where Duel Monsters is a competitive sport played at the Duel Academy, this spin-off follows a young duelist, Jaden Yuki, as he aims to become the next King of Games.

7. 10:00 AM - “Shaggy & Scooby-Doo Get a Clue!”: In this series, Shaggy and Scooby-Doo inherit riches and use their new resources to fight evil with futuristic gadgets.

8. 10:30 AM - “The Batman”: Continues to depict a younger Bruce Wayne in his early days as Batman, facing off against Gotham’s notorious criminals.

9. 11:00 AM - “Monster Allergy”: Following the adventures of Zick, a young boy who can see monsters, and his friend Elena Potato as they navigate through a world filled with supernatural beings.

10. 11:30 AM - “Johnny Test”: Concluding the morning, this show follows the adventures and experiments involving Johnny Test, his talking dog Dukey, and his genius twin sisters.

This revitalized lineup under The CW4Kids banner aimed to blend continuing popular series with new additions to offer a dynamic range of programming that catered to the diverse interests of its young audience. With a mix of action, comedy, and fantasy, the block sought to maintain its competitiveness in the crowded landscape of children’s entertainment by appealing to both loyal viewers and attracting new ones.
Write a forum convo in early June announcing Magi-Nation, Skunk Fu and World of Quest’s removal, the 3 4Kids shows arriving and the one returning show, Incidentally the website banner now has 6 characters, each from a different show

User5: Would’ve loved to see more of “Skunk Fu!” though. Guess it’s time to look for DVDs.

User1: Agreed. It’s always hard to see favorites go. Let’s hope these new additions can fill those shoes. Don’t forget to mark your calendars for June 21, folks! This summer’s going to be interesting. 📅🍿

Mid-September brought some insights into the viewing preferences of the CW4Kids audience, and it's clear that the new lineup has caught the attention of viewers both young and old. Here are the five most watched shows in mid-September:

1. **“Yu-Gi-Oh! 5Ds”**: Racing to the top of the viewer charts, “Yu-Gi-Oh! 5Ds” has captivated audiences with its combination of high-speed Turbo Duels, compelling narrative, and the ever-popular Yu-Gi-Oh! card game. Yusei Fudo's quest to become the best and his battles against the Dark Signers have resonated with fans, making it the most-watched show.

2. **“The Spectacular Spider-Man”**: Swinging into second place, “The Spectacular Spider-Man” continues to thrill audiences with Spider-Man’s heroic deeds and Peter Parker's personal dilemmas. The engaging stories, coupled with classic and new villains, prove that Spider-Man remains a beloved character among CW4Kids watchers.

3. **“Winx Club”**: Magic and fairy adventures captivate the third spot with “Winx Club.” The series’ blend of fantasy, action, and the trials of growing up enchant viewers, highlighting the universal appeal of the Winx fairies and their journeys through the magical universe.

4. **“Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Fast Forward”**: The futuristic adventure of the Ninja Turtles has garnered considerable attention, making it the fourth most watched show. The fresh setting and new characters, alongside the timeless appeal of the TMNT franchise, have attracted a wide range of viewers eager for action-packed storytelling.

5. **“Dinosaur King”**: Rounding out the top five, “Dinosaur King” has roared its way into the hearts of viewers. The combination of dinosaur battles, adventure, and the quest to protect the world from evil has proven to be a hit, especially among younger audiences fascinated by prehistoric creatures.

This mid-September snapshot reflects the diverse tastes of CW4Kids audiences, from the action and adventure of superheroes and mystical creatures to the strategic battles of card games. The rankings also suggest a successful integration of new and returning series into the lineup, appealing to both loyal fans and attracting new viewers.
Write a Top 3 with the lighter hearted shows

Mid-September has shown that among the dynamic and action-packed lineup of CW4Kids, there's a significant audience appreciation for the lighter-hearted, more comedic, or whimsically themed shows. These series provide a delightful contrast to the high-octane adventures, showcasing the broad appeal of the programming. Here are the top 3 lighter-hearted shows that have captured the hearts of viewers:

1. **“Kikoriki”**: Climbing to the top of our lighter-hearted category, “Kikoriki” has proven to be a massive hit. Its appeal lies in the humorous and sometimes absurd adventures of its round, colorful characters who, despite their simplicity, delve into complex life lessons about friendship, creativity, and problem-solving. The whimsical world of “Kikoriki,” devoid of any real villain but full of challenges and learning opportunities, resonates with audiences looking for lighthearted entertainment with depth.

2. **“Johnny Test”**: Always a crowd-pleaser, “Johnny Test” secures the second spot with its blend of slapstick humor, science fiction, and the everyday trials of being a kid. Johnny's misadventures, often instigated by his genius twin sisters' inventions, deliver a mix of chaos, comedy, and heart. It’s the quintessential story of a boy and his (talking) dog facing the world, one experiment at a time, appealing to viewers who enjoy comedic antics mixed with a dash of action.

3. **“Winx Club”**: While “Winx Club” is deeply rooted in the magical girl genre and features its share of battles and villains, it also shines with its lighter moments of friendship, romance, and personal growth, earning it the third spot. The series appeals to those who enjoy a good dose of fantasy and whimsy alongside their action, making it a unique blend that offers heartwarming stories, humor, and the power of teamwork and understanding. The daily lives of the fairies at Alfea, their interactions, and the lighter, comedic moments amidst their adventures provide a comforting escape with valuable lessons in resilience and kindness.

These top 3 lighter-hearted shows within the CW4Kids lineup demonstrate the network's commitment to providing a range of content that can entertain, enlighten, and engage audiences of all ages, showcasing the power of storytelling that brings joy, laughter, and a sense of wonder.

conversation.content: Write a forum convo where Nicktoons UK seems to be slightly shifting their schedule around, Bunsen is a Beast, Danny Phantom and Avatar have been replaced with a Monster Block (Monster High/AAHH! Real Monsters/Monster Allergy), Rest of the lineup is the same Spongebob/Loud House/Pokemon mix, Also, Pokemon Advanced is replacing XYZ next week

**Thread Title:** New Nicktoons UK Schedule Changes - Monster Block Incoming!

---

**SpongeBobFan44**: Hey everyone, have you seen the latest Nicktoons UK schedule? Looks like **Bunsen is a Beast**, **Danny Phantom**, and **Avatar** have been replaced. Now there’s a whole Monster Block with **Monster High**, **AAHH! Real Monsters**, and **Monster Allergy**. What’s up with that?

---

**LoudHouseLover21**: Yeah, I noticed that too! I'm kinda bummed about **Danny Phantom** and **Avatar** being replaced, those were my go-to shows after school. The Monster Block sounds interesting though, haven't seen **Monster Allergy** in ages. But I’ll miss my daily Avatar fix for sure.

---

**PokeMaster98**: Did anyone catch that **Pokemon Advanced** is replacing **XYZ** next week? They keep switching these up. I was really getting into the XYZ series. Hopefully, Advanced will be just as good. At least the SpongeBob and Loud House mix is still the same.

---

**MonsterManiax**: Totally psyched for the Monster Block! **AAHH! Real Monsters** is a classic, and I’ve been a **Monster High** fan for years. It's a nice switch-up, but I do get why some might miss the old lineup. Variety is the spice of life, though, right?

---

**NickNostalgia**: Can't believe they're sidelining **Danny Phantom** and **Avatar**. Those are some seriously iconic shows. The Monster Block could be cool for a bit, but I hope they bring back the classics soon. Also, mixing in more Pokémon never hurts, but the constant series switching is a bit much.

---

**AvatarAangFan**: This is really disappointing. Replacing **Avatar**? That show has such a strong fan base and it’s timeless. I understand trying out new themes like the Monster Block, but Avatar should be a staple! Guess it’s time to dust off the old DVDs.

---

**GhoulGirl**: Honestly, I'm here for the Monster Block! It’s perfect for the Halloween season if they decide to keep it around for a bit. Plus, **Monster High** has a lot of fans that will be thrilled. **Monster Allergy** is an underrated gem too. Still, the absence of **Danny Phantom** seems like a missed opportunity during a monster-themed block.

---

**Pikachu4Ever**: Welp, there goes my daily XYZ binge. **Pokemon Advanced** is okay, but XYZ had some epic battles. Hope Advanced has some good stuff too. At least **SpongeBob** and **The Loud House** are untouched. They kinda act as the backbone for Nicktoons' schedule anyway.

---

**DannyPhanatic**: Removing **Danny Phantom** just when I thought there was a resurgence in interest... Not cool, Nicktoons UK, not cool. He's practically a monster-fighting hero himself. Would've fit right in with the block. Guess I'll have to stick to fan communities for my ghost boy fix.

---

**RealMonstersFan**: Finally, **AAHH! Real Monsters** is getting the love it deserves! That show was way ahead of its time. Sad to see some favorites go, but this does shake things up. Maybe it’ll introduce these classics to a new audience. Can’t wait to see Ickis, Oblina, and Krumm back on my screen!

---

**Thread Moderator**: Thanks for all your insights, everyone! It's clear there are mixed feelings about the schedule change. For those missing the old shows, remember, schedules often rotate, so they might be back sooner than you think. For now, why not give the new Monster Block a chance? You might find a new favorite!

---
Write a tweet saying "It's Zick over Danny, If the Monster Block isn't your thing then Ash is jetting off to Hoenn next week"

"It's Zick over Danny in the latest Nicktoons switch-up! 📺 If the Monster Block lineup isn't quite your vibe, gear up as Ash heads off to Hoenn next week in Pokémon Advanced! ✈️🍃 #Nicktoons #MonsterBlock #PokémonAdvanced"

Write a forum convo where Grizzly Tales seems to be losing half its time slots at late nights (show only airs  to fulfil independent quotas, as it is produced by Honeycomb Animation and CITV) replaced with My Dad the Rockstar (could have sworn it would have been Pokemon or MonAll)

**Thread Title:** Grizzly Tales Slotted Down? My Dad the Rockstar Takes Over!

---

**TalesOfTerror**: Did anyone else notice **Grizzly Tales** got slashed in half on the late-night roster? I thought it was a solid choice for those looking to enjoy something a bit different. Now it's just to fill those independent quotas since it’s from Honeycomb Animation and aired on CITV. Replaced by **My Dad the Rockstar**? Was expecting more Pokémon or even Monster Allergy to take its place. Thoughts?

---

**RockstarRiffs**: Honestly didn't expect **My Dad the Rockstar** to make a comeback, especially not at the expense of **Grizzly Tales**. I've got nothing against it, but the shift is…unexpected. Thought they’d double down on Pokémon or something more in line with current trends.

---

**AnimationAdvocate**: It’s a shame to see **Grizzly Tales** pushed back. I get the vibe they’re only keeping it to meet quotas, which feels a tad disrespectful to the show. As for **My Dad the Rockstar**, it’s an interesting choice. Maybe it's a play for nostalgia?

---

**QuotaConundrum**: Let's face facts, folks. Filling quotas is a big part of scheduling decisions, and **Grizzly Tales** fits that niche for them. **My Dad the Rockstar** coming in might just be their way of shaking things up. Perhaps it tested well in groups we're not aware of?

---

**LateNightLurker**: **Grizzly Tales** was my late-night guilty pleasure! ☹️ The eerie vibe was perfect right before bed. **My Dad the Rockstar** is okay, but it doesn't hit the same spot. Seems like a weird choice to replace something so unique.

---

**NostalgiaKnight**: Wait, people are upset about **My Dad the Rockstar**? I loved that show! Sure, it’s sad about **Grizzly Tales**, but isn't variety the spice of life? Maybe they’re just trying to appeal to a broader audience at the late-night slot.

---

**MonsterAllergyFan**: Really thought they'd pick **Monster Allergy** to replace it, considering the Monster Block and all. Strange decision. **My Dad the Rockstar** has its charm, but feels off for the late-night vibe **Grizzly Tales** offered.

---

**GrizzlyGuru**: Disappointed but not surprised. **Grizzly Tales** always felt like a show that was underappreciated, thrown in to check a box rather than celebrated for its storytelling. Here’s hoping it finds its way back to a more prominent slot. As for **My Dad the Rockstar**, might give it a shot; who knows? It could grow on me.

---

**RockRevival**: TBH, **My Dad the Rockstar** returning is a win for me. I miss shows that aren’t afraid to be a little weird and wild. This might not be the popular opinion, but let’s give it a chance before we write it off completely for not being Pokémon or **Monster Allergy**.

---

**Thread Moderator**: This thread is lively! Good to see so many passionate opinions. Remember, the TV landscape is always changing, and who knows what the future holds? Maybe **Grizzly Tales** will get more slots back or **My Dad the Rockstar** will become the next big hit. Keep the discussions respectful and keep sharing your thoughts!

---

Write a forum convo where MA is their 3rd biggest acquired show, 2nd is The Garfield Show, 1 is Pokemon of course, They have been trying multiple tactics to increase its popularity, including frequently pairing it up with other monster related shows (even bringing back ARM)

**Thread Title:** MA Trying to Claw Its Way Up - Will Teaming Up with Other Monsters Do the Trick?

---

**MonsterMash45**: So, it looks like **Monster Allergy (MA)** is now officially the 3rd biggest acquired show on the network, just trailing behind **The Garfield Show** and of course, the unbeatable **Pokémon**. Noticed they’ve been trying to boost its popularity by pairing it up with other monster-themed shows. Even saw **Aaahh!!! Real Monsters (ARM)** got brought back into the mix. Think this will give MA the bump it needs?

---

**GarfieldFanatic**: Honestly, it’s a smart move but **The Garfield Show** has its own loyal audience because, well, it’s Garfield. **MA** has its charm, but it’s fighting an uphill battle. Monster mania is cool, but does it have what it takes to stand next to Pokémon? Pairing it up with classics like **ARM** is clever, but only time will tell.

---

**PokeMasterX**: Every show has its day, but Pokémon’s throne is pretty much untouchable. That said, **MA** has been getting more attention since the monster-themed programming kicked in. The pairings make for a fun, themed block that’s been quite enjoyable. It certainly sets the right atmosphere for **MA** to thrive.

---

**AaahhFan**: Thrilled to see **ARM** back in the lineup! If anything, I tune in for that nostalgia hit and stick around for **MA**. It’s a fun show with a lot of potentials. This strategy could introduce it to new viewers who come for the monsters and stay for the story.

---

**AnimationAnalyst**: The tactic here is pretty clear: they’re attempting to create a monster universe of sorts to leverage the thematic continuity between shows. **MA** benefits from this association, particularly when paired with well-loved shows. It’s a solid strategy for audience crossover but boosting it past **The Garfield Show**—that's a tall order.

---

**MonsterKid2000**: **MA** has always been underrated IMO. Pairing it with the likes of **ARM** just highlights what fans of monster genres enjoy. It’s a smart play, and I’ve definitely found myself watching more of it since the pairings started. Plus, who doesn’t love a good monster mash-up?

---

**ClassicToonLover**: Is it just me, or have they been pushing **MA** really hard lately? I mean, I appreciate the effort to diversify, but I worry that forcing it into these blocks might deter some folks. It should stand on its own merits. That being said, the monster block has been entertaining.

---

**DigitalDuo**: At the end of the day, it’s all about content consumption. By cleverly packaging **MA** with thematic shows, they’re not just trying to boost its viewership but also enhancing the overall viewing experience. It’s a smart way to capitalize on monster mania, inviting viewers to dive deeper into that world.

---

**MonsterHighway**: Love or hate the strategy, it’s definitely got people talking about **MA** more. Plus, seeing **ARM** again is a total bonus. There’s a certain genius in revitalizing interest in monster themes this way. **MA** might just surprise us and climb up the ranks.

---

**Thread Moderator**: Interesting points all around! It’s great to see such varied perspectives on the network’s strategy with **Monster Allergy** and its pairing with other monster-centric shows. This could indeed be the beginning of a new era for monster-themed programming. Let's keep the conversation respectful and see how this monster block evolves!

Write a follow up where the channel has occasionally had its HD feed rebranded as pop up channels, "NickSpongeBob", "NickHorridHenry" and most recently "NickGarfield", The next pop up is in 2 weeks, and has been promoted during the most recent airing of the Spongebob movie

Write a interview where the current CEO of five, confirms this (five is Channel 5, owned by Paramount, In this UK, they both have the same CEO, the five channels and the Nick ones)

**Interview with the CEO of Five and Nickelodeon UK, Discussing Programming Strategies and Future Plans**

**Interviewer:** Thank you for joining us today. There’s been a lot of speculation about scheduling and programming strategies, particularly regarding shows like **Aaahh!!! Real Monsters (ARM)**. Can you shed any light on this?

**CEO:** Absolutely, and thank you for having me. There has been a lot of discussion recently, and I'd like to clarify our stance and thought process behind these decisions. Our programming strategy, particularly with the integration of shows like **ARM** and its pairing with **Monster High (MH)** and **Monster Allergy (MA)**, was indeed designed with a specific purpose in mind.

**Interviewer:** There’s been talk that **ARM**’s reintroduction was primarily to support **MA**, especially after **Horrid Henry** was no longer part of the lineup. Can you confirm this?

**CEO:** I can confirm that. When we lost **Horrid Henry**, it created a gap that we needed to fill. **MA** has a strong potential, and we saw an opportunity to create a themed block that could not only support **MA** but also reintroduce viewers to **ARM**. It was a strategic move intended to bolster the ratings for **MA** and provide a cohesive viewing experience that capitalized on the popular monster theme.

**Interviewer:** So, does this mean that **ARM** is likely to be phased out again soon?

**CEO:** While I wouldn't say "phased out," our programming is always under review to ensure it meets the viewers' interests and our strategic goals. **ARM**’s current run is tied to the performance and reception of this themed block. We are always exploring new content and partnerships to keep our lineup fresh and engaging. If something more aligned with our audience's preferences and our strategic direction emerges, we might adjust our schedules accordingly.

**Interviewer:** Understanding that, is there a search for a new popular third-party show to join the lineup?

**CEO:** Indeed, there’s always a search for exciting content that can resonate with our audience. Our goal is to provide a diverse range of programming that entertains and engages our viewers. While I can’t dive into specifics at this stage, I assure you that several discussions are in progress to bring new and thrilling content to our channels.

**Interviewer:** How do you balance between popular international content and the need to fulfill independent content quotas?

**CEO:** It's a careful balancing act. We're committed to supporting independent productions and fulfilling our quotas, as it's essential for the diversity of content and supporting the local industry. At the same time, we understand our audience has a broad range of interests, including international hit shows. Our strategy involves striking a balance that satisfies these requirements while ensuring a varied and interesting lineup for our viewers.

**Interviewer:** Finally, can you give us a hint about future plans for the channels?

**CEO:** Without revealing too much, I can say we’re excited about what’s on the horizon. We're looking into more theme-based blocks, similar to the monster theme, and are in talks for new series that have the potential to become viewer favorites. We’re also examining ways to bring more interactive and immersive experiences to our audience. So, stay tuned!

**Interviewer:** Thank you for your time and the insight into the channel's strategies and outlook. We look forward to seeing what’s next for Five and Nickelodeon UK.

**CEO:** It was my pleasure. Thank you for having me, and I'm just as excited about the future.

Write a blog post where they are trying to replace Pokemon early

### Nickelodeon UK's Strategic Shift: Moving Beyond Pokémon

As the vibrant world of children's television continues to evolve, channels are constantly under pressure to keep their lineups fresh and engaging. Nickelodeon UK, a staple in quality children’s entertainment, is no stranger to adapting its programming to meet the rapidly changing interests of its young audience. A recent development has seen the channel preparing to pivot away from one of its most iconic offerings, "Pokémon," despite having two years remaining on its contract. This move has sparked speculation and a buzz of anticipation about what might come next.

#### The Pokémon Phenomenon

For decades, "Pokémon" has been a cornerstone of children's television, capturing the imagination of millions around the globe. Its success lies in its captivating stories, endearing characters, and the universal appeal of its "Gotta Catch 'Em All!" mantra. Nickelodeon UK's decision to start distancing itself from the Pokémon franchise thus comes as a surprise to many fans who have grown up with Ash, Pikachu, and the countless adventures across the Pokémon world.

#### A Strategic Evolution

Insiders suggest that this shift is a strategic response to the changing landscape of children's media consumption. With the rise of streaming services and on-demand viewing, traditional TV channels are challenged to offer content that can not only compete with the vast libraries available online but also cater to the new interests emerging from this digital age.

Moreover, Nickelodeon UK’s intensive push of Pokémon-themed content, including making it the theme for their next pop-up channel, may be a move to maximize the franchise's potential while it's still part of their repertoire. This "PokéBlitz" could very well be a celebration of the franchise’s legacy on the channel, giving it the send-off it deserves.

#### Looking Ahead: What's Next for Nickelodeon UK

The impending post-Pokémon era for Nickelodeon UK points to a future where the channel is placing bets on new and possibly original content to fill the void. Recent trends show a leaning towards themes and genres that resonate with today’s kids, who are more in tune with social media trends and global issues than any generation before them.

Speculation is rife about potential replacements. There's a strong case for more interactive and educational content, shows with environmental messages, or even series that incorporate technology and coding—skills that are becoming ever more important in today's digital world. Nickelodeon's recent pop-up ventures, such as "NickTooniverse," show a willingness to experiment and innovate, suggesting that whatever comes next will be both fresh and forward-thinking.

#### Embracing Change

Change can often be met with trepidation, but it is also a doorway to new opportunities. For Nickelodeon UK, moving on from Pokémon is a bold step into uncharted territory. It's a chance to redefine what children's programming can be and, in doing so, remain a leader in an industry that never stops moving.

For fans, while the prospect of losing a beloved franchise might be bittersweet, there's also the excitement of discovering new worlds and characters to fall in love with. Nickelodeon UK's journey beyond Pokémon promises to be one worth watching.

In conclusion, as we say goodbye to the familiar faces of Ash and Pikachu, let’s stay tuned to see how Nickelodeon UK will continue to innovate and entertain the next generation of viewers. The Pokémon legacy will undoubtedly be a hard act to follow, but if anyone's up to the task, it's Nickelodeon UK.

Thread Title: New Nicktoons UK Schedule Changes - Monster Block Incoming!

—

SpongeBobFan44: Hey everyone, have you seen the latest Nicktoons UK schedule? Looks like Bunsen is a Beast, Danny Phantom, and Avatar have been replaced. Now there’s a whole Monster Block with Monster High, AAHH! Real Monsters, and Monster Allergy. What’s up with that?

—

LoudHouseLover21: Yeah, I noticed that too! I’m kinda bummed about Danny Phantom and Avatar being replaced, those were my go-to shows after school. The Monster Block sounds interesting though, haven’t seen Monster Allergy in ages. But I’ll miss my daily Avatar fix for sure.

—

PokeMaster98: Did anyone catch that Pokemon Advanced is replacing XYZ next week? They keep switching these up. I was really getting into the XYZ series. Hopefully, Advanced will be just as good. At least the SpongeBob and Loud House mix is still the same.

—

MonsterManiax: Totally psyched for the Monster Block! AAHH! Real Monsters is a classic, and I’ve been a Monster High fan for years. It’s a nice switch-up, but I do get why some might miss the old lineup. Variety is the spice of life, though, right?

—

NickNostalgia: Can’t believe they’re sidelining Danny Phantom and Avatar. Those are some seriously iconic shows. The Monster Block could be cool for a bit, but I hope they bring back the classics soon. Also, mixing in more Pokémon never hurts, but the constant series switching is a bit much.

—

AvatarAangFan: This is really disappointing. Replacing Avatar? That show has such a strong fan base and it’s timeless. I understand trying out new themes like the Monster Block, but Avatar should be a staple! Guess it’s time to dust off the old DVDs.

—

GhoulGirl: Honestly, I’m here for the Monster Block! It’s perfect for the Halloween season if they decide to keep it around for a bit. Plus, Monster High has a lot of fans that will be thrilled. Monster Allergy is an underrated gem too. Still, the absence of Danny Phantom seems like a missed opportunity during a monster-themed block.

—

Pikachu4Ever: Welp, there goes my daily XYZ binge. Pokemon Advanced is okay, but XYZ had some epic battles. Hope Advanced has some good stuff too. At least SpongeBob and The Loud House are untouched. They kinda act as the backbone for Nicktoons’ schedule anyway.

—

DannyPhanatic: Removing Danny Phantom just when I thought there was a resurgence in interest… Not cool, Nicktoons UK, not cool. He’s practically a monster-fighting hero himself. Would’ve fit right in with the block. Guess I’ll have to stick to fan communities for my ghost boy fix.

—

RealMonstersFan: Finally, AAHH! Real Monsters is getting the love it deserves! That show was way ahead of its time. Sad to see some favorites go, but this does shake things up. Maybe it’ll introduce these classics to a new audience. Can’t wait to see Ickis, Oblina, and Krumm back on my screen!

—

Thread Moderator: Thanks for all your insights, everyone! It’s clear there are mixed feelings about the schedule change. For those missing the old shows, remember, schedules often rotate, so they might be back sooner than you think. For now, why not give the new Monster Block a chance? You might find a new favorite!

—
Write a tweet saying “It’s Zick over Danny, If the Monster Block isn’t your thing then Ash is jetting off to Hoenn next week”
“It’s Zick over Danny in the latest Nicktoons switch-up! 📺 If the Monster Block lineup isn’t quite your vibe, gear up as Ash heads off to Hoenn next week in Pokémon Advanced! ✈️🍃 #Nicktoons #MonsterBlock #PokémonAdvanced”
Write a forum convo where Grizzly Tales seems to be losing half its time slots at late nights (show only airs to fulfil independent quotas, as it is produced by Honeycomb Animation and CITV) replaced with My Dad the Rockstar (could have sworn it would have been Pokemon or MonAll)
Thread Title: Grizzly Tales Slotted Down? My Dad the Rockstar Takes Over!

—

TalesOfTerror: Did anyone else notice Grizzly Tales got slashed in half on the late-night roster? I thought it was a solid choice for those looking to enjoy something a bit different. Now it’s just to fill those independent quotas since it’s from Honeycomb Animation and aired on CITV. Replaced by My Dad the Rockstar? Was expecting more Pokémon or even Monster Allergy to take its place. Thoughts?

—

RockstarRiffs: Honestly didn’t expect My Dad the Rockstar to make a comeback, especially not at the expense of Grizzly Tales. I’ve got nothing against it, but the shift is…unexpected. Thought they’d double down on Pokémon or something more in line with current trends.

—

AnimationAdvocate: It’s a shame to see Grizzly Tales pushed back. I get the vibe they’re only keeping it to meet quotas, which feels a tad disrespectful to the show. As for My Dad the Rockstar, it’s an interesting choice. Maybe it’s a play for nostalgia?

—

QuotaConundrum: Let’s face facts, folks. Filling quotas is a big part of scheduling decisions, and Grizzly Tales fits that niche for them. My Dad the Rockstar coming in might just be their way of shaking things up. Perhaps it tested well in groups we’re not aware of?

—

LateNightLurker: Grizzly Tales was my late-night guilty pleasure! ☹️ The eerie vibe was perfect right before bed. My Dad the Rockstar is okay, but it doesn’t hit the same spot. Seems like a weird choice to replace something so unique.

—

NostalgiaKnight: Wait, people are upset about My Dad the Rockstar? I loved that show! Sure, it’s sad about Grizzly Tales, but isn’t variety the spice of life? Maybe they’re just trying to appeal to a broader audience at the late-night slot.

—

MonsterAllergyFan: Really thought they’d pick Monster Allergy to replace it, considering the Monster Block and all. Strange decision. My Dad the Rockstar has its charm, but feels off for the late-night vibe Grizzly Tales offered.

—

GrizzlyGuru: Disappointed but not surprised. Grizzly Tales always felt like a show that was underappreciated, thrown in to check a box rather than celebrated for its storytelling. Here’s hoping it finds its way back to a more prominent slot. As for My Dad the Rockstar, might give it a shot; who knows? It could grow on me.

—

RockRevival: TBH, My Dad the Rockstar returning is a win for me. I miss shows that aren’t afraid to be a little weird and wild. This might not be the popular opinion, but let’s give it a chance before we write it off completely for not being Pokémon or Monster Allergy.

—

Thread Moderator: This thread is lively! Good to see so many passionate opinions. Remember, the TV landscape is always changing, and who knows what the future holds? Maybe Grizzly Tales will get more slots back or My Dad the Rockstar will become the next big hit. Keep the discussions respectful and keep sharing your thoughts!

Write a forum convo where MA is their 3rd biggest acquired show, 2nd is The Garfield Show, 1 is Pokemon of course, They have been trying multiple tactics to increase its popularity, including frequently pairing it up with other monster related shows (even bringing back ARM)
Thread Title: MA Trying to Claw Its Way Up - Will Teaming Up with Other Monsters Do the Trick?

—

MonsterMash45: So, it looks like Monster Allergy (MA) is now officially the 3rd biggest acquired show on the network, just trailing behind The Garfield Show and of course, the unbeatable Pokémon. Noticed they’ve been trying to boost its popularity by pairing it up with other monster-themed shows. Even saw Aaahh!!! Real Monsters (ARM) got brought back into the mix. Think this will give MA the bump it needs?

—

GarfieldFanatic: Honestly, it’s a smart move but The Garfield Show has its own loyal audience because, well, it’s Garfield. MA has its charm, but it’s fighting an uphill battle. Monster mania is cool, but does it have what it takes to stand next to Pokémon? Pairing it up with classics like ARM is clever, but only time will tell.

—

PokeMasterX: Every show has its day, but Pokémon’s throne is pretty much untouchable. That said, MA has been getting more attention since the monster-themed programming kicked in. The pairings make for a fun, themed block that’s been quite enjoyable. It certainly sets the right atmosphere for MA to thrive.

—

AaahhFan: Thrilled to see ARM back in the lineup! If anything, I tune in for that nostalgia hit and stick around for MA. It’s a fun show with a lot of potentials. This strategy could introduce it to new viewers who come for the monsters and stay for the story.

—

AnimationAnalyst: The tactic here is pretty clear: they’re attempting to create a monster universe of sorts to leverage the thematic continuity between shows. MA benefits from this association, particularly when paired with well-loved shows. It’s a solid strategy for audience crossover but boosting it past The Garfield Show—that’s a tall order.

—

MonsterKid2000: MA has always been underrated IMO. Pairing it with the likes of ARM just highlights what fans of monster genres enjoy. It’s a smart play, and I’ve definitely found myself watching more of it since the pairings started. Plus, who doesn’t love a good monster mash-up?

—

ClassicToonLover: Is it just me, or have they been pushing MA really hard lately? I mean, I appreciate the effort to diversify, but I worry that forcing it into these blocks might deter some folks. It should stand on its own merits. That being said, the monster block has been entertaining.

—

DigitalDuo: At the end of the day, it’s all about content consumption. By cleverly packaging MA with thematic shows, they’re not just trying to boost its viewership but also enhancing the overall viewing experience. It’s a smart way to capitalize on monster mania, inviting viewers to dive deeper into that world.

—

MonsterHighway: Love or hate the strategy, it’s definitely got people talking about MA more. Plus, seeing ARM again is a total bonus. There’s a certain genius in revitalizing interest in monster themes this way. MA might just surprise us and climb up the ranks.

—

Thread Moderator: Interesting points all around! It’s great to see such varied perspectives on the network’s strategy with Monster Allergy and its pairing with other monster-centric shows. This could indeed be the beginning of a new era for monster-themed programming. Let’s keep the conversation respectful and see how this monster block evolves! Write a follow up in May where the Monster block closes, or has MH and ARM removed from it, The former goes back to only airing on regular Nick, where the latter becomes Paramount+ only, The remaining show is becoming pretty popular, even replacing TMNT Fast Forward next week,

Thread Title: The Big Shake-Up: Monster Block Ends, MH and ARM Move On, MA Takes Over!

—

MonsterBlockBuster: Wow, big news, folks! Just read that the Monster Block is officially closing down. Monster High (MH) is heading back to regular Nick, and Aaahh!!! Real Monsters (ARM) is moving to Paramount+ exclusively. Interestingly, Monster Allergy (MA) seems to be the sole survivor, not just staying put but also taking over TMNT Fast Forward’s slot next week. Looks like MA is gaining some serious traction. Thoughts?

—

TMNTfan1987: This is bittersweet. Sad to see TMNT Fast Forward replaced, but it’s intriguing that MA is the one taking up the mantle. This show’s been quite the dark horse, huh? Must say, its popularity seems to be skyrocketing. Curious to see how this will play out.

—

DigitalStreamer: So, ARM is a Paramount+ exclusive now. This seems like a move to bolster their streaming content with proven fan-favorite titles. As for MH moving back to regular Nick, seems like a strategic repositioning. MA’s success must be really turning heads for it to snag more prime slots.

—

MonsterMashup: Honestly, MA’s strong performance is a testament to its quality and the network's strategy in pushing monster-themed content. While I’ll miss the variety the Monster Block offered, it’s exciting to see one of the underdogs getting its well-deserved spotlight.

—

NickNostalgic: It's always a rollercoaster with these schedules, isn't it? Moving MH and ARM feels like they're banking a lot on MA. With its place confirmed in the lineup, replacing even TMNT, MA's got a lot to live up to. Excited yet cautious about these changes.

—

GarfieldGuru: Wasn't expecting MA to be the last monster standing. The shift back to regular Nick for MH and ARM becoming a streaming exclusive is a sign of the times, I guess. Content is moving fluidly between platforms. MA really needs to capitalize on this opportunity now.

—

PokeMaster98: While MA stepping up is cool and all, I was really hoping the Monster Block would bring about a new era of dedicated themed programming. It's a shame to see it dismantle so soon. At least MA seems to be thriving, which is a win for its fans.

—

AnimationAdmirer: The landscape of TV and streaming is indeed evolving. MA taking over TMNT’s slot is huge, signaling a shift in viewer interests or at least in network strategy. Curious to see if MA will become as iconic as its predecessors.

—

MonsterHighLover: Mixed feelings here. Happy for MA but sad to see MH being shuffled back to regular Nick, and ARM to Paramount+. The dynamics of where and how we watch our favorite shows are certainly changing. MA’s success represents a bold new direction for the network.

—

Thread Moderator: This shift surely marks an interesting turn in the ongoing saga of our favorite shows and how they're presented to us. Whether it's the end of an era or the start of a new chapter, it’s the fans who keep these shows alive with their enthusiasm and support. Let’s watch closely as MA steps up to its new role in the lineup. Keep the conversation respectful and stay tuned for further changes!

Thread Title: Zick Joins Sky On-Demand Elite & Monster Block Wrap-Up Campaign!

—

SkyWatcher101: Big news! Just noticed Zick has made it to the Sky on-demand banner, joining icons like SpongeBob, Lincoln (from The Loud House), Pikachu, and Garfield. This is a huge step up for Monster Allergy. Really solidifies its position among the top-tier shows. Also, saw the ads about the Monster Block ending. Looks like they’re really sending off the other shows with some creative flair!

—

AdAdmirer: Those ads were pretty clever! Saw one saying, “The extracurricular trip is over for the girls,” obviously hinting at Monster High's departure. And the “We’re heading back to Paramount+” for Aaahh!!! Real Monsters was a nice touch. But that tagline for Zick, “From May 1st, Zick will have his work REALLY cut out for him, MORE adventures, MORE fun,” got me really excited for what’s next!

TurtlePowerFan: Did anyone catch an ad for the Turtles though? With TMNT Fast Forward being replaced by Monster Allergy, I hoped they'd get a creative send-off too. Maybe something like, “The Turtles are taking a pizza break…” missed opportunity if they didn't do one.

—

MonsterMash45: Zick making it to the Sky on-demand banner is massive! Shows just how much faith they have in Monster Allergy to carry that torch. The promotional push with those ads sounds like they're setting the stage for MA to really take off. Can't wait for “MORE adventures, MORE fun”!

—

ParamountPlusPals: Sad to see Aaahh!!! Real Monsters being dubbed as going ‘back to Paramount+’. It feels like the end of an era with the Monster Block winding down. But hey, the focus on Zick is promising! Hopefully, this will bring a fresh wave of excitement and maybe even new fans.

DigitalDialogue: Those ad campaigns are a stroke of genius – offers closure to fans of the departing shows while hyping up what’s to come for Zick. The Sky on-demand banner inclusion speaks volumes about the expected popularity surge. It’s like Zick has been officially inducted into the hall of fame alongside SpongeBob and Pikachu!

NostalgiaNerd: Rewatching those ads, they’re bittersweet but beautifully done. “The extracurricular trip is over for the girls” had me chuckling yet sad. Monster Allergy taking over the prime slot is huge; the network must be banking heavily on its success. Hope it lives up to the hype!

—

GarfieldGuru: Kinda loving that Monster Allergy is getting so much attention. Zick joining the ranks of iconic characters like Garfield on the Sky banner is something I didn’t see coming this quickly. This boost in visibility might just introduce MA to audiences who've missed out so far.

—

AnimationAnalyst: It's intriguing to see how networks maneuver their assets to adapt to viewer trends and demands. Zick's prominence is a calculated move, possibly aiming to fill the void left by other series. The creative ads add a touch of class to the transition. Curious to see how the viewership adjusts come May 1st.

Zick's ascension to the Sky on-demand banner cements his place among animated nobility. As one chapter closes with heartfelt goodbyes, another awaits with untold adventures. Lamput. Write a forum convo months later where a kid REALLY misses Kikoriki, The parent says they've transitioned to Squish, Horrid Henry and The Owl & Co well, but still ask for Kikoriki all the time

**Thread Title:** CartoonLand's Programming Changes: Who Else Misses Kikoriki?

**Post by:** CartoonLover1990

Hey everyone,

Lately, my kid has been really missing Kikoriki on CartoonLand. I get that channels need to refresh their lineups now and then, but it's been tough on the little one. We've found some solace in Squish, Horrid Henry, and The Owl & Co, which have been fantastic in their own right, but it's just not the same. It's adorable yet heartbreaking how they frequently ask if Kikoriki will ever come back. Has anyone else's kid been in a similar boat? How are you folks managing?

**Reply by:** ParentingInToonTown

Absolutely understand where you're coming from, CartoonLover1990. My two are the same - we've transitioned well enough to the new shows, and they adore The Owl & Co, but Kikoriki held a special place. It was a uniquely charming show. I've tried finding some episodes online and setting up little 'nostalgia' viewings at home to ease the transition. Maybe that could work for you?

**Reply by:** NostalgicNick

Feeling the Kikoriki blues here too! Although, not a parent, but I grew up with Kikoriki and was sad to see it go from CartoonLand's lineup. It's interesting how certain cartoons, even the less mainstream ones, can leave such a lasting impact. On the bright side, it's given me an excuse to dive into other similar shows for that nostalgic kick. 

**Reply by:** ToonParent101

CartoonLover1990, you're not alone. My youngest had a similar phase when CartoonLand phased out Dude, That's My Ghost. What really helped us was getting engaged with the newer shows, like you mentioned - Squish, Horrid Henry, and The Owl & Co. But they occasionally still ask for the ones that are gone. Sometimes introducing them to completely different activities (like drawing or outdoor play) when they bring up missing Kikoriki helps divert their attention and lessen the asking over time.

**Reply by:** Tech savvy Dad

Hey, all! A bit off the beaten path, but I took to compiling playlists of similar shows and even found some Kikoriki episodes and clips online. Creating a media library for easy access helped keep the fond memories of Kikoriki alive while gradually welcoming new favorites into the fold. Sometimes blending old and new keeps everyone happy - or at least wards off the "When is Kikoriki coming back?" questions for a little while longer!

**Post by:** CartoonLover1990

Thank you all for your thoughtful responses and suggestions! It's comforting to know we're not alone in this transition period. I appreciate the idea of creating nostalgia viewings and blending the old with the new. It's about making new happy memories while cherishing the old ones, right? Gonna start looking up some episodes online and planning a fun viewing party. Thanks again, everyone!
Write a follow up where a user says their kid likes Chaotic, Skatoony and Johnny Test, also YooHoo, but misses Kikoriki and that "show with the orange blob" (obviously mentioning Lamput)

**Thread Title:** Remembering Kikoriki and "That Show with the Orange Blob"

**Post by:** ToonMixMaster

Hey all,

Jumping back into this conversation because it really resonated with me the other day. My kid's current favorites on CartoonLand are Chaotic, Skatoony, Johnny Test (though only Season 1 is on, they just can't get enough of it!), and YooHoo and Friends. It's great to see them so engaged with these shows, but they can't help missing Kikoriki. And, oh, the "show with the orange blob" – they meant Lamput, and now I realize how much of a staple it had become in our household.

It's fascinating to see what sticks with them and what becomes a fleeting memory. I’m trying to find ways to keep these shows alive in our daily routines, maybe through drawing characters or storytelling, but I’d love more ideas or to hear if any of you are dealing with similar nostalgic requests from your little ones!

**Reply by:** RetroToonRanger

Totally understand where you're coming from, ToonMixMaster! Lamput and Kikoriki have such unique premises and memorable characters; it's hard to find anything quite like them airing nowadays. Since you’re seeking ideas, maybe try some DIY crafts based on these shows? There are tutorials online for creating simple animations or even clay models. It could be a fun project to do together and help fill that void left by their absence on CartoonLand.

**Reply by:** CartoonLover1990

Hey ToonMixMaster, we're in the same boat here. My little one loved Lamput—the hilarity of that orange blob's escapades was unmatched. Since reading your post, I've been inspired to hunt down some episodes and clips online. Maybe you could do the same and have a special movie night featuring Kikoriki and Lamput? Also, creating a scrapbook with images or drawings from their favorite episodes could be a nice way to keep the memories of their beloved shows fresh.

**Reply by:** TechSavvyParent

I went through a similar phase with my kids. They were massive fans of both Kikoriki and Lamput. Not to mention, the current love affairs with Chaotic and Skatoony. What worked for us was creating a "mixtape" (well, a digital playlist) of their favorite episodes across these shows, including any online finds of Kikoriki and Lamput. It became a fun weekend ritual to watch together. It might not bring the shows back to CartoonLand, but it keeps the spirit alive at home.

**Reply by:** AnimatedHeart

Your kiddos have great taste, ToonMixMaster! Chaotic, Skatoony, and the others are classics in their own right. Missing Kikoriki and Lamput shows they've got a deep appreciation for good storytelling and fun characters. Have you thought about introducing them to comic books or graphic novels that have a similar vibe? Sometimes, new yet familiar storylines can help bridge the gap left by beloved shows. Plus, it's a great way to encourage reading and imagination!

**Post by:** ToonMixMaster

Thank you all for your ideas and encouragement! I love the suggestions of creating a digital playlist and engaging in some arts and crafts. The comic book or graphic novel idea sounds like a fantastic way to keep their imaginations fueled and maybe ease the longing for Kikoriki and Lamput a bit. You've all given me a lot of great avenues to explore with them, keeping the spirit of their favorite shows alive and well. Much appreciated!
Write a tweet where after Lamput had vanished, the kid thought the scientists who were always chasing him had finally got him, He forgot about it after he saw a different shoe

"Just witnessed the most heartbreaking yet hilariously adorable moment - after noticing #Lamput was missing from the TV lineup, my kiddo solemnly declared 'The scientists finally caught him.' 😢 But all was forgotten when a new show caught his eye. Out of the mouths of babes! #KidsTV #MovingOn"
Write a forum convo about how kids reacted to Lamput vanishing, without notice

**Thread Title:** The Mysterious Disappearance of Lamput: Kids' Reactions

**OP by ToonWatcher101:**

Hey fellow parents,

Has anyone else's kiddo noticed that *Lamput* vanished from CartoonLand without any notice? My 8-year-old was a huge fan, and the sudden disappearance of the show has led to some interesting reactions at home. One day, it was their go-to post-dinner relaxation, and the next, poof, gone! I was curious how your kids reacted and how you're managing their questions. 

**Reply 1 by AnimationAdmirer:**

Yes! We're in the same boat. My two were baffled when *Lamput* was nowhere to be found. My youngest actually thought our TV was broken and wanted to help "fix" it so Lamput could come back! It was both sweet and sad. I just told them maybe Lamput is on a super secret mission and we have to wait and see if he comes back.

**Reply 2 by SciFiMom:**

I've had a tough time explaining to my daughter. She thinks the scientists finally caught Lamput and got really upset about it. We've been drawing our own "Lamput escapes" comics to make up for it. It's our little coping mechanism, creating new adventures for Lamput until (or if) the show comes back.

**Reply 3 by CartoonDad83:**

It's been a rollercoaster here too. My son asked if we could send a letter to the TV channel asking where Lamput went. So, we actually did. I helped him write a cute letter, not expecting a response but hoping it might help give him closure. On the bright side, it sparked his interest in writing and storytelling.

**Reply 4 by GeekyGuardian:**

Our reaction was a bit different. My kid shrugged and moved on to a new favorite show within days. Kids are resilient! Though, I must admit, *I* miss Lamput. It was one of the few shows we all enjoyed together. I’ve been secretly hoping for its return or at least for an official statement about why it was removed.

**Reply 5 by NostalgicNanny:**

This happened so suddenly! My granddaughter has been asking about Lamput every day. We've started making up our own stories about where Lamput could be, turning it into a fun bedtime story routine. It's our way of keeping the character alive in our home. I hope CartoonLand brings it back or at least gives us some closure.

**Reply 6 by CalmCollector:**

Interesting to see all the different reactions. It's a bummer when shows vanish without notice, more so for kids who form attachments to these characters. We've pivoted to finding similar content online, but there's a "Lamput-shaped" hole in our viewing schedule for sure. Does anyone have recommendations for similar shows to fill the gap?

**OP's Follow-Up:**

Thanks for sharing your experiences and coping strategies, everyone. It really highlights how shows like *Lamput* impact our families. I love the creativity many of you have shown in dealing with the absence. Let's keep our fingers crossed for some news about our beloved orange blob, and in the meantime, maybe take up some of these fantastic suggestions to keep the spirit of Lamput going strong in our homes.
Write a follow up where the kid slowly forgot about it after seeing a different show, 3 actually,

**Thread Title:** Update: Moving On From Lamput - The Power of New Favorites

**OP by ToonWatcher101:**

Hello again, everyone!

I wanted to provide a bit of an uplifting update following our previous discussions on our kids' reactions to the mysterious disappearance of *Lamput* from CartoonLand. It's been a few weeks since I started this thread, and I've witnessed a fascinating transition in my 8-year-old's viewing habits.

After the initial sadness and repeated questions about why Lamput was gone, something unexpected happened. We stumbled upon three new shows that quickly captured my child's imagination, much to my surprise and relief.

1. **"Adventure Hunters"**: A show filled with mysteries and exploration, which hooked him instantly. The vibrant characters and their endless quests for ancient artifacts around the world seem to have filled the adventurous gap left by Lamput.

2. **"Space Rascals"**: This animated series about a group of mischievous kids exploring the galaxy in their spaceship introduced a whole new world of excitement. The sci-fi element added a fresh layer of intrigue and wonder that he absolutely loves.

3. **"Magicville"**: A magical town with talking animals and mystical events at every turn. This show, in particular, has sparked not just an interest in magic but also in drawing and storytelling, as he now creates his own magical tales.

Seeing this shift has been remarkable. While he occasionally mentions Lamput with a nostalgic tone, these three shows have largely filled the void and expanded his horizons. It's a testament to how resilient and adaptable children can be, finding new sources of joy and creativity.

Has anyone else observed similar changes in their kids' viewing preferences? Would love to hear more stories about how they've moved on or diversified their interest in shows!

**Reply 1 by SciFiMom:**

So heartwarming to read this, ToonWatcher101! We’ve had a similar experience in our house. "Space Rascals" has been a hit here too! It's amazing how quickly kids can bounce back and find new interests. It makes me think that as much as they loved Lamput, it’s the excitement of discovery and the joy of storytelling that really captivates them.

**Reply 2 by GeekyGuardian:**

Thanks for sharing this! It really resonates with us. My child found a new love in "Magicville" as well, and it's been wonderful seeing her imagination run wild. I agree, kids are incredibly resilient and open to new adventures. It's a lovely reminder that there’s always something new that can capture their hearts and minds.

**Reply 3 by AnimationAdmirer:**

Incredible update, ToonWatcher101! "Adventure Hunters" has become my kids' new obsession. While they still have a soft spot for Lamput, the new shows have taught them that there's a vast world of stories out there waiting to be discovered. It’s comforting to see them so engaged and happy again.

**Reply 4 by CartoonDad83:**

Your story gives me hope! We haven’t quite found our new favorites yet, but seeing how your child has moved on and embraced new shows is encouraging. Will definitely check out the three shows you mentioned. Here’s to new adventures and the endless magic of storytelling!
Write a tweet about BFDI helping with a kid losing 3 shows in one month

"Just witnessed the magic of BFDI! After a tough month where my kiddo lost 3 favorite shows, #BFDI stepped in like a charm, sparking joy & laughter in our home again. 🌟 The resilience & adaptability of children, supported by the right content, is truly remarkable. #KidsTV #NewFavorites"
